On 2 April 1998, in the Wangaratta Magistrates Court, Mr John McPhee received a 12-month suspended gaol sentence and a $30,000 fine, after pleading guilty to more than 30 charges of dishonest use of company funds, and he was ordered to pay a total of $103,870.50 restitution to the liquidators of McPhee Meatpacking Pty Ltd. One of the charges referred to the purchase of 12 racehorses for $23,350, paid for by a Wodonga Meats cheque, and written into the books as 56 cattle brought for slaughtering at the Blainey Abattoir in New South Walesâalso owned by Mr McPhee.

The charges were brought against McPhee by the ASC. They originally included 33 Victorian charges: 17 of false accounting, 16 of theft; and 48 Commonwealth charges: 16 of failing to act honestly as a director, 16 of improper use of his position as a director to obtain benefit for another, and 16 of false accounting. He pleaded guilty to 17 charges of false accounting and 16 of failing to act honestly as a director.

Wodonga Abattoir has reopened since Wodonga Meats and McPhee Meatpacking, the original company, went broke. Another company of which McPhee is director continues to own the land on which the meatworks is situated and, of course, still operates. The company that now operates the abattoir has two of McPhee's trusted former employees as directors, and a labour hire firm employs the labour. John McPhee is believed to still be in full control of the entire operation. He attends the works on a daily basis and continues to exercise the authority of an employer over the people employed to work there.

So we have a case where, even when unscrupulous employers are discovered and convicted in courts, they are still able to operateâand to operate in a manner which suggests to me that they are not fit and proper persons to actually function in the meat industry. To me, this is a corrupt practice, a practice which this parliament ought to pay attention to.

I noticed today that we debated a particular bill by Senator Mackay which would address some of these issues in terms of employment security of workers employed by these unscrupulous employers who are, in fact, undermining not just the living conditions of workers employed in their particular enterprises, but also I think the legitimate actions of proper employers who do pay wages and conditions, who do meet their legal obligations and, of course, who do conduct their business in a fair manner. In so doing, I think the unfair advantage that the unscrupulous and, I think in this case, the criminal are taking over other employers in the industry who do engage in ethical business practices ought be condemned and, as I say, action ought to be taken by this parliament.

We have a similar case at Grafton. The South Grafton Abattoir was operated by R.J. Gilbertson (Queensland) Pty Ltd. However the land, plant, buildings and equipment are owned by R.J. Gilbertson Pty Ltd, the holding company, and approximately 50 workers at the abattoir were employed by Giltech which had no realisable assets. What appears to have happened as a result of various corporate manoeuvres is that, through the transfer of assets and/or cash between the various Gilbertson companies, the employing company was stripped of the funds to pay these entitlements which should have been paid to those workers at the abattoir in South Grafton.

One has to ask the question: what sorts of laws are there in this country that allow this sort of theft to go on and these sorts of actions to occur in such a manner where the perpetrators of these, what I regard as, crimes are not prosecuted at law? These matters are under investigation by the Australian Securities Commission. I trust that that commission does take these matters through to their rightful end and that these sorts of actions are stamped out. Workers are entitled to the protection of proper industrial laws. They should, in fact, have the opportunity to take benefit from those laws and not be subject to these sorts of abuses and corrupt actions.

subdebateinfo.title: Victorian Central Highlands: Regional Forest Agreement

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak tonight about a matter of extreme importance to the natural environment of my home state of Victoria. It is indeed of importance to Australia but particularly to Victoria. I refer to the recently signed regional forest agreement for the Victorian Central Highlands.

speech.para: We have heard a lot of mistruths in this place about RFAs generally from the government, and the Central Highlands RFA is no exception. Last month in question time, Senator Parer said that the Central Highlands RFA is:

. . . a win for both jobs and the environment. One hundred and sixteen thousand hectares have been added to the central highlands reserve system. This represents a 64 per cent increase in the reserve system.
He continued:
. . . the central highlands regional forest agreement will create jobs, protect the environment, and I commend it to the Senate.

I would like to look at some of those statements and try to work out the real situation. It is worth doing, not just because of the importance of the Central Highlands region, but also because the region has come up in this chamber on a number of occasions in question time, matters of public importance and debate over legislation.

The Central Highlands Regional Forest Agreement was signed by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Premier of Victoria on 27 March this year. At the time of the announcement of that signing, it was described by environment groups as `an enormous con trick, a glossy PR exercise designed to make it seem that the longstanding conflict over native forest logging has been solved'.

As with the East Gippsland and Tasmanian RFAs, the Central Highlands RFA process has been widely criticised for some dubious scientific methodologyâfor lack of proper survey data and questionable statistical sampling techniques. Done correctly from the start, the RFA process could have had some integrity and offered us at least some chance of lasting peace in the forests. Instead, the ecological importance of the Central Highlands region and many others is at risk.

Forty vegetation classes have been identified in the Central Highlands region, of which 20 are considered rare, endangered or vulnerable. The Central Highlands also contains 25 species of mammals, birds, reptiles, frogs and fish, and 15 plant species that are listed under Commonwealth or state legislation as being threatened. These species include Victoria's faunal emblem, the Leadbeater's possum, the Baw Baw frog, the grey goshawk, the spotted tree frog, the crimson spider orchid, owl species, and many more. The area contains magnificent mountain ash forests, fern gullies, riverine forests and other vegetation types. It is also virtually on Melbourne's doorstep and, therefore, into the future will become an even more important recreational and aesthetic asset.

The 116,000 hectares claim is a nonsense. These areas are either largely mountaintops and other areas that would not have been logged anyway, or, alternatively, they are not big enough to be considered secure and viable reserves as habitat for threatened species. In reality, no further secure or significant reserves have come out of this process. The RFA fails its most obvious environmental testâthe state's faunal emblem, the Leadbeater's possum, is a species in serious trouble, yet the logging giant Amcor has access to two-thirds of the possums' known remaining habitat.

The RFA between Victoria and the Commonwealth agrees that, even if a world heritage assessment of these forests within the eucalypt theme were to conclude that they were of international significance and would meet the world heritage criteria, the Commonwealth has actually agreed not to proceed unless all governments agree and, given that this includes the Victorian government, that is highly unlikely. This is all spelled out in clause 29 of the agreement.

Similarly, the agreement says that no recommendations for further listings to the Register of the National Estate shall proceed unless jointly agreed between the federal and state governments. In our view this is an abrogation of the federal government's re sponsibility, and this is precisely why so many people are very worried about this government's proposed changes to environmental laws due to come into this chamber, I understand, some time this year. In essence, it is about state rights, not the rights of the planet and the myriad of creatures that inhabit these wonderful forests.

The public consultation process for those changes to the federal environment laws has been grossly inadequate, with only one month for the community to comment on a very vague discussion paper put out by the office of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer). The Central Highlands was the same story with many groups claiming consultation was tokenistic and was there to simply legitimise predetermined outcomes. Certainly, if you believe the book by Pamela Williams entitled The Victoryâand I have no reason to doubt itâabout the last federal election, this tokenism is certainly the case. That book goes into some detail about the deal which was done between the Liberal Party and the forestry industry prior to the last election. Certain agreements were already reached as far back as November 1995.

In clause 40 of the agreement, the Commonwealth has also agreed that Victoria's processes and systems provide for ecologically sustainable management of forest in the Central Highlands. Yet the parties also agree on badly needed improvements in later clausesâsuch as clause 48 which recognises the need to further develop appropriate mechanisms to monitor and review the sustainability of forest management practices. Also, clause 59 agrees that pest plant and animal control programs will be developed within five years. How then can the Commonwealth agree that Victoria's forest practices were, at the time of signing this RFA, already sustainable?

In clause 79, the agreement also allows for mining and exploration in the reserve system. In addition, no package of measures is yet available which would guarantee proper management of Aboriginal heritage. Clause 74 recognises this fact. And so it goes on.

Perhaps one of the most startling admissions in the agreement is contained in clause 81 regarding the Thompson catchment. This is the catchment that provides most of Melbourne's water supply. Logging within the catchment has been controversial for many years. A recent economic study concluded that the catchment is worth more in dollar terms for its water than for the returns which could ever come from logging. The RFA agrees to develop a long-term timber harvesting and water production strategy for the catchment `when timber resource data becomes available in 1999'. Obviously, we have been proceeding for all these years without even basic information, as this RFA now admits.

I argue that successive federal governments have dragged various states into national competition policy arrangements, and they have used various means to do so including the competition principles agreement. But what do we see in the RFA? The Commonwealth agrees that pricing and allocation arrangements for wood from public forests are solely matters for Victoria. In other words, unlike other COAG agreements about the pricing of water, the Commonwealth government have given away their involvement in these matters. They may as well have said `We don't care, even if state governments want to give our forests away for nothing.'

I have visited many places in this RFA region, and I cannot for the life of me see how this agreement can claim to be ecologically sustainable. After logging, these coupes look more like battlefields. The Central Highlands RFA, as described by Senator Parer, is not a win for the environment. It is, rather, a lost opportunity, squandered by this government.

talk.start.para: âLast Tuesday, in the concluding minutes of the adjournment debate, I raised the problems encountered on a regular basis by many Tasmanian shippers in forwarding their cargo through the port of Melbourne. Shippers from Tasmania are very much at the mercy of shipping companies and some very bad waterside practices. There are difficulties in booking space and getting containers, loading is frequently unreliable, ships hardly ever dock or leave on time, and to keep up with their schedule shipowners will take the decision to pull out of port, leaving on the docks containers booked on the vessel, to hopefully be loaded on the next ship. I am referring to the export trade.

speech.para: Exporters do not have faith that containers will be shipped in the manner they request, or on the deck they request. If a tarpaulin is put on a container at the shipper's expense to protect their product, the tarpaulin may be stolen and almost certainly will be damaged. Exporters find they have no right to expect their product to be cared for and protected once out of their sight. In Australian shipping, customers had no rights 25 years ago, and for many Tasmanians little has changed today. Reforms are supposed to have occurred, but people from Tasmania, when shipping overseas, ask where they are, certainly in terms of the costs.

Until we have a sincere approach on reform in which it can be acknowledged and accepted by all parties in the shipping industry that the customer should and must always be right, there is unlikely to be any worthwhile reform. The customer, the shipper, must have a right to expect that he actually can and will get what he pays for. The customer, the shipper, has the right to expect that everything possible will be done throughout the booking of space, the ordering of empty containers, the receival of the product at the wharf, storage at the wharf, loading onto the ship, the voyage, discharge and delivery at the point of destination, to ensure that the paying customer is always right. The customer has a right to expect nothing less. Then, and only then, will we have reform that is working. Then, and only then, can the customer, and Australia, become world competitive.

No wonder exporters are frustrated. No wonder they are cynical about the Melbourne waterfront. One Tasmanian exporter became so frustrated about shipping his product through Melbourne that he actually provided additional tarpaulins to be put at Melbourne wharf so that when the original one went missing he had a replacement. This particular exporter reckoned that wharfies must really like camping. Not a week went by without the same exporter receiving complaints from customers in Melbourne and Sydney that their consignments were one or two bags short.

Then again, fresh vegetables from the north-west coast of Tasmania, grown in that amazing red soil, are world renowned. Wharfies and their families must be really well fed on Tasmanian vegetables, particularly from the north-west coast. A textile importer innovatively changed the wording on their crates to ensure they received their full order on arrival at their depot. The wharfies' families must be well clothed too.

Shippers complain of the high cost of shipping. It was not too many years ago when it was difficult to find shipping executives after lunch. It could be argued that our shipping managers, our stevedores and our port authorities let go the management and control of the Australian waterfront. Weren't these the people who did the deals because it was the easy way to keep the ports working? What about the $12 pay increase to wharfies in 1991, in the middle of a recession? It was wrong then, and we have continued inefficient work practices ever since.

We believe that the position can be redeemed. It is going to take a great deal of effort if we in Australia are to get these things done. But, without what I call total waterfront reform, this country will never be world competitive. New Zealand has certainly tackled the problem, and so must Australia. The situation is embarrassing for us as a country and it is also embarrassing for our exporters. Recently when in New Zealand I visited the port authority in Auckland and found there that the wet handling chargesâthe tug charges and associated eventsâby the Port of Auckland Authority were five times cheaper than any port in Australia. We are not talking about 10 per cent or 20 per cent but five times cheaper than any port in Australia.

There must therefore be total reform, and it must be honest reformâby all the partiesâto end the decades of poor work and management practices on our docks which have added to exporters' costs and reduced our international competitiveness. As a Tasmanian senator, I look forward to total reform, particularly from the port of Melbourne.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 30 March 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) Prior to 6 December 1997 what discussions did the Minister have with representatives of the National Farmers Federation regarding the creation of a new stevedoring operation or stevedoring workforce for the Australian waterfront; (b) when and where did these discussions occur; (c) who was present; and (d) what was the content of the discussions.

(2) (a) Was the Minister present at a meeting in Melbourne on 18 September 1997 at which the contents of the ACIL report on waterfront reform was discussed; (b) who else was present at the meeting; (c) were members of the National Farmers Federation present; and (d) were copies of the report given to any persons other than the Government representatives.

(3) Has the Minister discussed the contents of the ACIL report, or any other waterfront consultancy reports commissioned by the Government, with any persons other than Government ministers, officials or the consultants themselves; if so, with whom, when and where.

(4) (a) How much money has been paid by the Government to each of the following consultants on waterfront reform listed at (4)(c); (b) what was the nature of the work performed by each consultant; and (c) are there any other consultancies relating to the Government's waterfront reform strategy that do not appear in the following list: David Trebeck of ACIL, Paul Houlihan, Stephen Webster, John Davies, BGC Media, Mark Textor of Australian Research Strategies, Jonathon Gaul of Canberra Liaison, Minter Ellison, Corrs Chambers Westgarth and National Institute of Labor Studies.
(5) (a) In what capacity is Dr Stephen Webster employed in the Minister's office; (b) is he on a fixed-term contract; and (c) what level of remuneration is he being paid.

(6) Is Dr John Davies employed in the Minister's office; if so: (a) in what capacity; (b) when did he commence; (c) is he on a fixed-term contract; and (d) what level of remuneration is he being paid.

(7) (a) Which waterfront reform consultancies commissioned by the Government have produced written reports; (b) what is the approximate length of each of the reports; (c) what is the subject matter of each of the reports; and (d) when were they delivered to the government.

(8) What connection exists between the Government's waterfront reform consultancies and the Fynwest Pty Ltd attempt to train waterfront workers in Dubai; (b) what connection exists between Government's waterfront reform consultancies and the P&C stevedoring operation being established at Webb Dock; (c) if there is no connection, what alternative proposals does the Government have for improving waterfront productivity; and (d) when will the Government begin implementing these proposals.

(9) (a) What discussions has the Minister had with Chris Corrigan, Peter Scanlon or any representatives of Patrick Stevedoring regarding waterfront reform; (b) when and where did these discussions occur; (c) what was discussed; and (d) was the possibility of sacking the entire Patrick Stevedoring workforce discussed.

(10) With reference to a minute from Darren Gillespie from the department, dated 10 March 1997, and headed `Meetings with Stevedoring Employers': (a) was action taken on the recommendation at the end of the minute that a further meeting involving the Prime Minister take place in April 1997; (b) did such a meeting occur; if so, when and where; (c) who was present; and (d) what was discussed.

(11) (a) Is the Minister aware of the affidavits signed by Lucas Rene and Richard Scougall on 25 February and 24 February 1998, respectively, detailing accusations of fraudulently conducted crane licence tests by PC Training Services Pty Ltd; (b) have any inquiries into these allegations been made; if so, what inquiries and with what outcome; and (c) has any action been taken in this matter, or is there any proposed action.
(12) (a) Has the Minister had any discussions, either in person or by telephone, with either Michael Wells or Peter Kilfoyle; if so, when, by what means, and where; and (b) what was discussed.
(13) Has there been any examination of alleged management inefficiencies and deficiencies in Patrick Stevedoring's operations; if so, what has been the outcome from such inquiries.

(14) (a) Since 8 January 1998 has Mr Peter Wilson, or any other member of the Minister's personal staff, contacted any stevedoring or other companies to urge them to publicly or industrially attack the Maritime Union of Australia; if so, who did they call, when, and what did he ask the companies to do.
